headline.main: Optimism's Bright Side: A Healthy, Longer Life

docs.abstract: New study of 90 law students finds that optimism may help prevent people from getting sick during stressful times; Dr Suzanne C Segerstrom of University of Kentucky says findings strengthen notion that thoughts and feelings can affect immune system (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: PEOPLE who look on the bright side have reason to be optimistic. Evidence suggests that they have healthier, longer lives than their gloom-and-doom counterparts. For years, research has shown that optimists weather coronary bypass surgery better and live longer with H.I.V. Now a new study suggests that positive thoughts are also good for healthy people.
